Description: Volkswagen AG agreed to plead guilty to three criminal felony counts and pay a $2.8 billion criminal penalty in connection with its scheme to use a defeat device to cheat on emissions tests mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency and the California Air Resources Board. In separate civil resolutions of environmental, customs and financial claims, VW agreed to pay $1.5 billion.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: In two related settlements, one with the United States and the State of California, and one with the U.S. Federal Trade Commission, German automaker Volkswagen AG and related entities agreed to spend up to $14.7 billion to settle allegations of cheating emissions tests and deceiving customers. Volkswagen agreed to offer consumers a buyback and lease termination for nearly 500,000 model year 2009-2015 2.0 liter diesel vehicles sold or leased in the U.S., and spend up to $10.03 billion to compensate consumers under the program. In addition, the companies agreed to spend $4.7 billion to mitigate the pollution from these cars and invest in green vehicle technology.

In a second partial settlement announced by the U.S. Department of Justice, the Environmental Protection Agency and the State of California, automakers Volkswagen AG, Audi AG, Porsche AG and related entities agreed to recall 83,000 model year 2009 through 2016 3.0 liter diesel vehicles sold or leased in the U.S. that are alleged to be equipped with defeat devices to cheat emissions tests, in violation of the Clean Air Act and California law. The settlement required Volkswagen to pay $225 million to fund projects across the country that will reduce emissions of NOx where the 3.0 liter vehicles were, are or will be operated.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: This settlement, which covered 3.0-liter diesel vehicles produced by VW, supplemented an early agreement concerning 2.0-liter cars. Both were outgrowths of allegations that the company cheated on emissions testing. In this case VW agreed to repurchase vehicles from customers at an estimated total cost of up to $4 billion. Bosch, which manufactured the device that enabled to cheating, was said to be making a contribution toward the cost of the buyback but no amount was cited in the announcement. Also see: https://www.ftc.gov/system/files/documents/cases/3227_ftc_30l_order_executed.pdf

This suit began as part of a racial harassment class action that was resolved in 2007 with a $9 million settlement (listed separately) but ended up being handled as a separate individual matter focusing on allegations that the company failed to hire Whitfield because of his race. The settlement included $934,122 for the plaintiff plus $850,000 in legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Whitfield v. International Truck And Engine Corporation

Description: Racial discrimination. The settlement included $4.5 million for the class and $4.5 million in legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Allen v. International Truck And Engine Corporation

Description: Volkswagen agreed to pay $570 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that the company sold and leased certain diesel vehicles equipped with illegal and undisclosed emissions defeat devices designed to circumvent emissions standards. This was part of a larger $14.7 billion settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-volkswagen-ag

VW agreed to pay $40 million in settlement of allegations of consumer fraud by misrepresenting vehicle emission teting resultss. Arizona did not take part in the multistate settlement finalized in June 2016 over the same violations.

The California Attorney General and the California Air Resources Board announced a $66 million settlement with Volkswagen over the company's use of defeat device software to bypass emissions controls in its Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche 3.0-liter diesel vehicles, in violation of California's environmental laws.  This was part of a larger $225 million settlement also involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-volkswagen-ag-0

The California Attorney General announced that, in addition to the historic $14.7 billion settlement by Volkswagen with federal and state agencies, the company would also pay California an additional $86 million in civil penalties as part of a second partial settlement over the company's use of defeat devices to evade emissions testing in its diesel vehicles.

Volkswagen agreed to pay $50 million to settle allegations it violated the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act (DTPA) and misled consumers by marketing and selling diesel vehicles as clean, even though it knew the cars were equipped with defeat device software to cheat on emissions tests.

Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and Porsche AG, as well as their American subsidiaries, agreed to pay over $157 million to ten states to settle environmental lawsuits challenging their secret use of unlawful defeat device software to conceal the true level of emissions from their vehicles.
Settlement of a state case concerning the use of defeat devices to conceal illegal emissions from diesel vehicles.

Volkswagen agreed to pay $6.5 million to resolve alleged violations of Vermont's consumer protection laws involving VW's false advertising claims about so-called Clean Diesel cars and the diesel engine emissions scandal.

The Oklahoma Atttorney General announced that it had reached an $8.5 million settlement with Volkswagen to resolve charges of deceptive advertising in connection with the company's use of illegal software to cheat emissions tests. This was separate from the multistate settlements reached by VW over the emissions cheating issue.

Volkswagen agreed to pay $69 million in settlement of allegations it violated New Jersey's clean air laws and defrauded customers by selling vehicles with devices that cheated emissions tests. New Jersey brought a stand-alone lawsuit in state court rather than join the multistate attorneys general action over the same allegations.
